abstract.t: From a user or developer point of view, it makes no sense for there to be a proliferation of definitions of URL nor for there to be a proliferation of incompatible implementations. This shouldn't be a competitive feature. Therefore there is a need for the organizations involved to update and reconcile the various Internet Drafts, Recommendations, and Standards in this area.

section.title: Brief History of URL standards
section.t: This section contains a very compressed history of URLs.

defined URLs as ASCII only. Although it was quickly determined that it was desirable to allow non-ASCII characters, shoehorning utf-8 into ASCII-only systems was unacceptable; at the time Unicode was not so widely deployed, and there were other issues. The tack was taken to leave "URI" alone and define a new protocol element, "IRI"; was published in 2005 (in sync with the update to the URI definition).

The IRI-to-URI transformation specified in had options; it wasn't a deterministic path. The URI-to-IRI transformation was also heuristic, since there was no guarantee that %xx-encoded bytes in the URI were actually meant to be %xx percent-hex-encoded bytes of a utf8 encoding of a Unicode string.

To address issues and to fix URL for HTML5, a new IRI working group <https://tools.ietf.org/wg/iri/charters> was established in IETF in 2009. Despite years of development, the group didn't get the attention of those active in WHATWG, W3C or Unicode consortium, and the IRI group was closed in 2014, with the consolation that the documents that were being developed in the IRI working group could be updated as individual submissions or within the "applications area" working group. In particular, one of the IRI working group items was to update , which is currently under development in IETF's application area.

Independently, the HTML specifications in the WHATWG and W3C redefined "URL" in an attempt to match what some of the browsers were doing. This definition (mainly a published parsing algorithm) was moved out into .
The world has also moved on. ICANN has approved non-ASCII top level domains, and neither and fully addressed IRI Encoding. Subsequently, the Unicode consortium produced .

section.title: Current Organizations and Specs in Development
section.t: There are multiple umbrella organizations which have produced multiple documents, and it's unclear whether there's a trajectory to make them consistent. This includes the IETF, the WHATWG, the W3C, Web Platform.org, and the Unicode Consortium.

section.title: IETF
section.t: The IRI working group closed, but work can continue in the APPS area working group. Documents sitting needing update, abandoned now, are three drafts (, , and ) intended originally to obsolete .
In addition, there's quite a bit of activity around URNs and library identifiers in the URN working group, work that is largely ignored by other organizations.

section.title: Problem Statement
section.t: The main problem is conflicting specifications that don't match each other and overlap.
Additionally, the following are issues that need to be resolves to make URL processing unambiguous and stable.

list.t: Nomenclature: over the years, a number of different sets of terminology has been used. URL / URI / IRI is not the only difference. chronicles a number of differences.
Parameterization: standards in this area need to define such matters as normalization forms and values for parameters such as UseSTD3ASCIIRules.
Interoperability: even after accounting for the above, there is a demonstrable lack of interoperability across popular libraries and browsers. identifies a number of such differences.

section.title: Outline of Potential Solution
section.t: This problem clearly requires a cross-organizational solution, specifically:

list.t: Build a plan to update or obsolete , , , and to be consistent with and . This may involve working to get the other specifications updated.

Change the goals to only obsolete specifications listed above that are not updated. Presuming that is updated, explicitly state that canonical URLs (i.e., the outout of the URL parser) not only round trip, but also are valid URIs.
Reconcile how and handle currently unknown schemes, update to state that registration applies to both URIs and URLs, and update to indicate that is how you register schemes.
Other than responsing to any feedback that may be provided, no changes to any Unicode Consortium product is required.
